Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Modeling Outbreak of COVID-19 Using Dynamic Survival Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration: The outbreak of COVID-19 has created a tremendous need for predicting both the dynamics and the size of regional COVID-19 outbreaks. Equally important is the need to determine the potential effects of early interventions such as school closures and mandatory or self-imposed quarantines. To answer these questions, this project will develop a general mathematical framework for analyzing the ongoing outbreak trends using data solely from partially observed new daily infection counts (also known as the epidemic curve). The PIâ€™s new framework will not assume any specific infectious or recovery periods (which are often unknown) or observable prevalence of the disease. The tools developed as part of this project will both help predict the rate of growth of new infections and estimate the effect of social distancing and other preventative measures on flattening the epidemic curve. The PI will use a new dynamical survival analysis approach to predict the trajectory of the COVID-19 epidemic for a mid-western region of the United States. Data from elsewhere in the world, like the city of Wuhan in China, will be used to calibrate the predictions. The project will also provide a practical interdisciplinary training for a PhD student and a post-doctoral fellow.<br/><br/>The modeling and predictive framework to be developed is fundamentally different from the traditional approach based on the incidence or prevalence counts in a compartmental SIR model. Specifically, the PI will apply the dynamical survival analysis (DSA) approach that considers aggregated mean field equations for the underlying large stochastic network and regards them as the approximate survival law of the infection times. The PI will use these DSA-based equations to model both the epidemic and recovery curves and compare them with the ones observed during the COVID-19 outbreak. The statistical analysis of epidemic data performed with the help of the new framework will allow the quick elucidation of the dynamics of an epidemic (for example, the basic reproduction number, R0) and the potential impact of interventions (such as quarantine or social distancing). The new framework will help provide a better understanding of how preventive behaviors affect COVID-19 dynamics via changes in the network structure and changes in disease transmission across edges in the network. This project will develop a user-friendly software package for computer simulations under different parameter and intervention scenarios (for example, vaccination schemes) that will lead to a better understanding of how to control COVID-19 transmission.<br/><br/>This grant is being awarded using funds made available by the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act supplemental funds allocated to MPS.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project aimed to refine methods for predicting and analyzing the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic, with a particular focus on the US Midwestern region. Throughout its duration, the team developed an innovative modeling framework grounded in dynamical survival analysis. This approach enabled them to estimate the time it takes for infections to spread within large, unpredictable networks. As a result, they gained deeper insights into epidemic behaviors, like the basic reproduction number (R0). Using this model, they conducted a thorough statistical analysis of epidemic data to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions, such as quarantine and social distancing. Additionally, the team developed user-friendly simulation software tailored to various scenarios, which was pivotal in strategizing how to effectively mitigate COVID-19 transmission.

Moreover, the team played an essential role in advising Ohio's pandemic response, using their expert modeling predictions to guide policy-making. Their research outcomes were shared widely through various publications and presentations at both national and international conferences, broadening the scientific community's understanding of the epidemic. They also collaborated with international institutions, such as the University of Nottingham and the Torino Technical University, promoting a global exchange of knowledge and expertise. One of their significant achievements was their ability to closely mirror real-world epidemic data through mathematical approximations across different scenarios.

The project significantly bolstered the global grasp of COVID-19's transmission and control mechanisms. It had a profound impact on steering the Ohio government's response during the epidemic's early stages. In partnership with the Ohio Governor's Office, the team developed and introduced tools to gauge the efficacy of early preventive measures. This knowledge was invaluable for understanding the virus's progression in the initial phases of the epidemic in the US Midwestern region.

Modified by: Grzegorz Rempala

  • Prediction of the number of COVID-19-related admissions to Ohio hospitals (dashed) for the time window from October 1, 2020, to January 1, 2021, based on data available as of October 1, 2020. The solid line represents the actual count of admissions
